div.p: HEALTH is one of the 16 major DIV1 content elements in the BIOGRAPHY section of entries defined as integral to mapping a woman's life. Within this element, discuss all serious events and issues associated with her health, both mental and physical. We are particularly interested in women's health issues and this element has an associated attribute value to indicate them. We hope to make connections between social, political and historical health issues (for example, the gendered nature of mental health) and the personal lives of women writers (the experience of a woman writer being incarcerated in a mental institution). While we are not interested in listing all health problems a woman writer encountered, we are interested in analyzing the effect of her health on her life and writing.

The HEALTH element should be placed in the appropriate chronological order within the Biography section. Use multiple HEALTH elements to record her health history at the appropriate stage of her biography. You can include both general summary statements about her health or just a CHRONSTRUCT, for example, in the case of major illnesses. A single optional attribute, ISSUE, distinguishes various aspects of HEALTH through attributes PHYSICAL, MENTAL, and FEMALEBODY.

div.codeblock: <HEALTH ISSUE="physical"><DIV2><HEADING>Back Injury</HEADING><CHRONSTRUCT><DATE>June 1930</DATE> <CHRONPROSE>FB fell heavily onto rocks and injured her back.</CHRONPROSE></CHRONSTRUCT>

Breast Cancer30 September 1811The large lump on FB’s breast was diagnosed (whether accurately or not) as breast cancer.

After being thought for a while inoperable, she underwent a ground-breaking but excruciating mastectomy.

<HEALTH ISSUE="mental"><DIV2><CHRONSTRUCT><DATERANGE FROM=”1959” TO=”1962”>At some time between 1959 and 1962</DATERANGE><CHRONPROSE>DM had a nervous breakdown, occasioned by the deaths of her long-time lover, her father, and her mother.</CHRONPROSE></CHRONSTRUCT></DIV2></HEALTH>

div.p: Include a discussion of a fatal illness inside a HEALTH element if you have plenty of material, but make sure to repeat the illness as the CAUSE of death inside the DEATH element.

Many personal experiences of illness recorded in Orlando relate to the historical and material politics of health. In order to facilitate research on such issues, try to include relevant terminology: breast cancer, anorexia, tuberculosis, epidemic, surgeon.
Question: Is suicide a health issue?
Answer: Yes. Include attempted suicides under HEALTH with an ISSUE=Mental attribute.
